- Maybe I'm not understanding this properly, but is there a use case for this other than ingestion?

I am working on some related code and notice that this issue I have met before too.

@xvrl After some investigation, I believe the reason for the discrepancy is due to performance of different components. For block based compression layout, the total time for reading column is composed of : copy byte buffer block + decompression + read values from byte buffer. 

`longs + lz4` takes more time on the decompression part, while `delta + lz4` take more time on the read value part. For readContinuous, the two differences kinda cancel out, making the performance similar. For readSkipping, the read value part is basically gone with so few reads, while the decompression part remains around the same, making `longs + lz4` take much longer.

I did some benchmark using the uncompressed strategy, which goes through the same process as lz4 for copy block + read value, with the only difference being no decompression step. The difference in time between lz4 and uncompressed should be the time for decompression. From the benchmarks below, it seems that readContinuous and readSkipping decompression time matches.

Note delta strategy is renamed to auto since the strategy could use delta, table, or longs depending on data cardinality and maximum offset.

```
enumerate
readContinuous
 auto           lz4  10  29.033 ¬± 1.111  ms/op
 auto  uncompressed  10  28.591 ¬± 0.911  ms/op
longs           lz4  10  20.878 ¬± 1.856  ms/op
longs  uncompressed  10  17.101 ¬± 0.358  ms/op
readSkipping
 auto           lz4  10   1.459 ¬± 0.069  ms/op
 auto  uncompressed  10   0.236 ¬± 0.123  ms/op
longs           lz4  10   5.889 ¬± 2.222  ms/op
longs  uncompressed  10   3.327 ¬± 1.929  ms/op

zipfLow
readContinuous
 auto           lz4  10  35.505 ¬± 0.744  ms/op
 auto  uncompressed  10  31.311 ¬± 1.022  ms/op
longs           lz4  10  33.904 ¬± 2.328  ms/op
longs  uncompressed  10  17.404 ¬± 0.690  ms/op
readSkipping
 auto           lz4  10   4.941 ¬± 0.360  ms/op
 auto  uncompressed  10   0.522 ¬± 0.141  ms/op
longs           lz4  10  18.387 ¬± 1.321  ms/op
longs  uncompressed  10   3.390 ¬± 2.403  ms/op


zipfHigh
readContinuous
 auto           lz4  10  26.399 ¬± 1.428  ms/op
 auto  uncompressed  10  23.593 ¬± 0.667  ms/op
longs           lz4  10  23.355 ¬± 1.868  ms/op
longs  uncompressed  10  17.335 ¬± 0.796  ms/op
readSkipping
 auto           lz4  10   2.914 ¬± 0.259  ms/op
 auto  uncompressed  10   0.383 ¬± 0.142  ms/op
longs           lz4  10   8.015 ¬± 0.590  ms/op
longs  uncompressed  10   3.406 ¬± 2.738  ms/op

sequential
readContinuous
 auto           lz4  10  29.491 ¬± 0.951  ms/op
 auto  uncompressed  10  28.636 ¬± 0.351  ms/op
longs           lz4  10  54.110 ¬± 0.894  ms/op
longs  uncompressed  10  17.035 ¬± 0.249  ms/op
readSkipping
 auto           lz4  10   1.335 ¬± 0.735  ms/op
 auto  uncompressed  10   1.079 ¬± 0.282  ms/op
longs           lz4  10  39.549 ¬± 0.544  ms/op
longs  uncompressed  10   3.472 ¬± 2.714  ms/op

uniform
readContinuous
 auto           lz4  10  31.522 ¬± 1.021  ms/op
 auto  uncompressed  10  33.260 ¬± 1.238  ms/op
longs           lz4  10  32.292 ¬± 1.532  ms/op
longs  uncompressed  10  17.211 ¬± 0.955  ms/op
readSkipping
 auto           lz4  10   0.746 ¬± 0.518  ms/op
 auto  uncompressed  10   0.528 ¬± 0.176  ms/op
longs           lz4  10  18.018 ¬± 1.105  ms/op
longs  uncompressed  10   3.302 ¬± 2.018  ms/op
```

I'm not sure why lz4 decompression is faster for auto compared to longs even though the compressed size are similar. Perhaps less work is done for auto decompression since the decompressed size is smaller.
@navis how much of a difference does this make to memory usage or batch ingestion time for your metrics in real world use case?
@fjy In the worst case, 1 min changed to 10 min (with full GC on every 10 seconds). We can just change max row count for incremental index but this was easier and effective.
@navis wow that's a big difference, cool
@fjy I will address the comment.

Following is what i am planning to do
1: Enum ColumnType {
    DIMENSION,
    METRIC
}
parallel to enum ValueType.
2: Identifying column type using availableDimensions and availableMetrics collections in storageAdaptor.
3: getColumnType() as new capability in ColumnCapabilities 
4: A new property in ColumnAnalysis
5: Required changes around ColumnAnalysis, SegmentAnalyzer and SegmentMetadataQueryRunnerFactory

The final response json would look like 

"signin": { "type" : "STRING", "size" : 100000, "cardinality" : 1944, columnType: "dimension"},
"count": { "type" : "STRING", "size" : 100000, "cardinality" : 1944, columnType: "metric"}

@fjy let me know if this seems right or if I missed something or if there is a better way of doing it.
Thanks in advance for your guidance.
@nishantmonu51 Thanks

StorageAdapter already has an api with name getColumnTypeName() for the 'type' field.
Need to think of some other name for it instead of ColumnType. 'FieldType' or 'ColumnCategory' maybe. 
Or change the existing api to getTypeName() to keep it consistent.

I can think of one more reason for that. Because LinkedHashMap only can remove one entry for one `put`, it can possibly exceed maximum bytes. If ever increasing sized object are to be added to it, it'll also grow ever.

@gianm @drcrallen I tested two options which both seem to work:

1) Upgrade Kafka client to 0.10 - downside is that users will have to upgrade their brokers as the 0.10 client is not compatible with 0.9 brokers. Upside? Bug fixes? Kafka Stream client support?

2) Force Maven to use lz4 1.2.0 for the extension AND introduce a mechanism to remove lz4 1.3.0 from the classpath passed to the peon. This could be done by running a regex on druid.indexer.runner.classpath in ForkingTaskRunnerConfig. We could a) either have it be done manually (add another property like druid.indexer.runner.classpathExclusions) or b) we could do it automatically if the task type is a Kafka task. Downside to a) is that it's another config that users who want lz4 would have to know to do, and b) it's a little black magicky but maybe acceptable.

Thoughts?

If we _really_ want to fix it, I think we should have a better classloader isolation story at the peon level. See https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2502 and https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2476 for more related items.

I haven't looked at the kafka client in depth, but how difficult would it be to support multiple versions of the kafka client, either in the same extension or multiple extensions?

@drcrallen hmm same extension - probably non-trivial and would require additional classloading work; different extensions - easy but ugly if you just cloned the extension, harder if you want to have a single copy of the source and use Maven configs to build two versions (since the API is not exactly the same between 0.9 and 0.10). I don't really love the idea of maintaining two versions just to support lz4 compression.

My main consideration in whether to move to 0.10 is how big of a nuisance broker updates would be for users. It can be done as a no-downtime rolling update so it's mainly the inconvenience of it I suppose. Again, it kinda feels like too much to ask for no benefit except for lz4 working (the other compression formats gzip and snappy work fine).

```
GroupByBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                   v1                -1                       4              4            100000           basic.A  avgt   25  260989.798 ¬± 12204.440  us/op
GroupByBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                   v2                -1                       4              4            100000           basic.A  avgt   25   81352.681 ¬±  5366.392  us/op
```

with cache,

```
GroupByBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                 v1                -1                       4              4            100000           basic.A  avgt   25  248414.170 ¬± 17031.688  us/op
GroupByBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                 v2                -1                       4              4            100000           basic.A  avgt   25   76909.636 ¬±  4504.446  us/op
```

Not a big difference but seemed good for six-line addition.

This introduces state where there was no state before in a way that is not thread safe. Even BufferIndexed.lastReadSize explicitly calls out that it is not thread safe. 

This needs either a contract change for Indexed such that it is designated not thread safe and all the due diligence that entails, or a change here to guarantee thread safety.
Unless there's some other strong precedence that Indexed does not need to be thread safe

@drcrallen right. it's not properly prepared for multi-threaded access. Originally I did this (in our version) in column selector level but tried here in lower level, which was not a good idea. can we close this?

I can see that other builds of `master` in TravisCI are also failing in the same module: https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/builds/155098852 https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/builds/152843594

Thanks Nishant for your suggestion. 
I looked at #2806 and read that people are concerned about the asymptotic complexity of the algorithm proposed there.
Looking at the metamarkets blog post about the new cost function, I liked how mathematical these guys were about defining the cost function, but I think it might be missing a piece.

In the context of machine learning, the common paradigm is:

optimization objective = cost function + regularization term

Could it be that the current balancer is missing the regularization term?
Usually, the cost function complexity grows linearly with the problem size but the regularization term has a constant complexity as it penalizes the parameters used in the cost function and is therefore independent of the number of datapoints a cost function iterates over.

In the concrete case of the balancer the regularization term could quantify the cost of executing the segment movements to counterbalance the benefit of moving them which is modeled by the cost function.
